texts.shortText: Laterally flattened and elongate-oval with thickish lips, single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail fin. Pectoral fin pale, with the lower few rays markedly elongated and free (hence common name) - these being used as support when resting on the bottom. Body colour pale with small red and brown spots, plus five broad unbroken brown vertical bars. Tail fin transparent and not striped.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Eastern Cape.

Smallish fish usually found singly and more commonly on deeper reefs of 10-30 m (but has been recorded from 5 m to at least 100 m). Often sits on the bottom using the thickened free lower pectoral rays as support and when disturbed swims lazily a few meters, then settles again.
Details unknown, but eggs probably develop in plankton.

Similar in body shape and habits to the Redfingers C. fasciatus, but that species tends to occur in more shallow waters, has a darker mottled body, a striped tail, and the vertical bars on the sides are broken and staggered at the level of the lateral line. The Twotone fingerfin Chirodactylus brachydactylus (note the confusingly similar but different genus name) is also similar in shape and habits, has a quite different colour pattern, being uniform brown with a large silvery patch across the side of the head and shoulder and five white dots along the lateral line.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 316).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 4 (p. 83).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 228).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 667).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 49).
